trustfund:
TF028622-GET-CONGO WILDLANDS PROTECT.
            & MANAGE.,TF028611-GET-PPA FOR CONGO WILDLANDS PROTECTION

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated marginally
            satisfactory. The project was successful in protecting
            several of Congo's important ecosystems: it established
            a national park in primary closed forest, a community
            reserve in an inundated forest, and a sanctuary in savannah
            and gallery forest, and reinforced an established reserve.
            However, the achievement of objectives is considered
            marginal due to the impact of civil war and unrest, the high
            turnover of senior government officials that delayed many
            activities, and the numerous misunderstandings between
            government and the trustee regarding project objectives and
            implementation. Project sustainability is unlikely. Both
            World Bank and Borrower performances are adjudged
            satisfactory. Principal lessons include: The cross-sectoral
            nature of the project initially resulted in little
            ownership. This was exacerbated by the large role of
            international nongovernmental organizations. By project end,
            both of these factors were seen as strengths and the project
            succeeded due to both government partnerships and the strong
            and independent role of the NGOs. Because NGOs were directly
            included in project management, continuity was maintained
            when government upheaval occurred. NGOs also provided
            cross-fertilization of ideas and solutions to problems never
            encountered by the government. And, the cross-sectoral
            nature and NGO involvement attracted a lot of international
            media, which promoted national ownership and international recognition.
